subject: Re: JUnit 3.8.1 with JDK 1.1.8

messageBody:
Thanks Jochen - great info, but as it turns out the problem was a call
to System.getProperties("user.home") in BaseTestRunner.java.

The embedded platform i'm working on does not support reading system
properties!

Thanks,
Leslie


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jochen Hiller" <jo.hiller@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Leslie,
>
> thats a real historical question ,-)
>
> I do not have an JDK 1.1.8 available, to do any testing. But, I did
a port
> of JUnit 3.8.1 for a very small virtual machine, called leJOS [1]. I
called
> this port leJOSUnit [2], which is OpenSouce, you can download to
have a look
> inside. leJOS is based on -target 1.1 byte code, so a √ç am
definitely sure,
> that leJOSUnit is running on JDK 1.1.
>
> The main thing to be done was avoid any Java reflection. I do not known,
> since when all the required reflection capabilities for JUnit 3.8.1 have
> been intoduced in J2SE.
>
> In leJOSUnit, the mechanism to setup a TestCase is very simple. Lets
see an
> example for a TestCase:
>
> public class OneTest extends TestCase {
> public OneTest(String name) {
> super(name);
> }
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(new OneTest("testOne"));
> suite.addTest(new OneTest("testTwo"));
> return suite;
> }
> protected void runTest() throws Throwable {
> if ("testOne".equals(getName())) {
> testOne();
> } else if ("testTwo".equals(getName())) {
> testTwo();
> } else {
> fail();
> }
> }
> public void testOne() {
> // ...
> }
> public void testTwo() {
> // ...
> }
> }
>
> So, the basic idea is to implement the runTest() and dispatch with a
static
> approach. A TestSuite can be implemented the known way:
>
> public class AllTests {
> public static void main(String[] args) {
> // put here a runner for your embedded platform, or a
> junit.textui.runner when a console is available
> // ... lejosunit.rcxui.TestRunner.main(suite());
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> suite.addTest(OneTest.suite());
> suite.addTest(TwoTest.suite());
> return suite;
> }
> }
>
> This is only a hint for which direction to look for. What kind of
error do
> you have ? Did you try to run the JUnit test suite against itself ?
>
> Bye, Jochen
>
> [1] http://www.lejos.org
> [2] http://lejosunit.sourceforge.net
>
>
> On 10/20/06, lchapman123 <leslie.chapman@...> wrote:
> >
> > Has anyone had success running JUnit 3.8.1 with JDK 1.1.8? I am
> > trying (unsuccessfully) to run the two together on an embedded
> > platform to no avail. I would like to rule out that it is an
> > incompatibility between the two distributions.
> >
> > Thank you!
> >
